files.description: Documents the atomic-claim schema, labeling rubric, dataset format, and how to run the curation/validation scripts end-to-end.
Defines the Python package, dependencies, console scripts, formatting/linting tools, and test configuration.
Provides the package entry point and exports the public schema and dataset utilities.
Implements the atomic-claim data model with machine-readable fields (subject, predicate, scope, provenance requirements) plus JSON serialization and validation.
Defines the supported/contradicted/insufficient labeling rubric with decision rules, edge-case guidance, and programmatic checks for label consistency.
Implements a small curated reference corpus loader (documents + citations) and utilities to index passages and resolve provenance pointers.
Defines the gold-annotation format tying atomic claims to evidence spans and labels, including validators for borderline-confidence slice constraints.
Provides a CLI to initialize a starter corpus, create/edit claim+annotation templates, validate JSONL files, and export a compact dataset slice.
Contains the curated reference documents/passages with stable IDs and citation metadata used for grounding claim labels.
Contains the initial borderline-confidence dataset slice with atomic claims, labels, and explicit provenance pointers into the reference corpus.
Tests schema/rubric/gold validators on known-good and known-bad examples to ensure labeling and provenance rules are enforced.

missionDescription: Define an atomic-claim schema + labeling rubric (supported/contradicted/insufficient) and build a small curated reference corpus + gold annotations to serve as the first 'borderline-confidence' dataset slice.
missionSuccessCriteria: Complete strategic task identified by Meta-Coordinator or escalated by Strategic Tracker

Curated insight (actionability 8-9/10): Provides a defensible evaluation and product stance for the 'borderline band' by shifting decisions to claim-level verification over a curated corpus, enabling tiered risk labeling and better measurem...
